SUCCESSFUL SEASON TO
A CLOSE
New Records Established in Five
Events. Rutgers Only League
Team to Gain Victory
The Hopkins Swimming Team
brought its season to a successful close last Saturday when it
finished second to Rutgers in the
The

MUSICAL CLUB TO ELECT OFFICERS AT SUPPER
Officers for next- year's season
of the Musical Club will be elected at a supper to be held in the
Barn on March 22. This meeting
will consist of a gathering of all the
members . of the Musical Club,
Who are expected to be present in
order to vote for next year's executives. Although the club's
season is not closed, the officers
are to be installed immediately
after this election. This is to
give the new men a chance to
learn the duties of their offices
under the guidance of the retiring officers.

DRAMATIC CLUB GIVES TWO PRESENTATIONS OF
ANNUAL PRODUCTION,"THE PURPLE MASK"
Cast Shows Evidence of Capable Coaching. Desch Makes Hit as
Sabine. Smallwood and Moore Take Leading Parts
Holding a large and approving audience in its grip from the rise
of the curtain in the first act until Armand de Treviere had made his
final escape, "The Purple Mask," a mystery-drama in five acts, was presented by the Johns Hopkins Dramatic Club at the Lyric Monday and
Tuesday nights.
The dullness of amateur performances is proverbial. "The Purple
Mask," however, judging by numerous encores and vehement applause,
was a distinct success. The members of the cast displayed ability far
beyond the capacity of the average amateur; the men demonstrated in
the portrayal of their parts, several of them extremely difficult, that the
lines had not been merely memorized.

In announcing fifteen thousand dollars as a goal, Mr.
Palmer believes that he has set a target which should be an
easy "bull-eye" for any wide-awake undergraduate body of
seven hundred students.
Opportunity is here offered to that large group of men
who ever bewail their inability to participate in college athletics, yet who always find fault with their progress, to prove
their good intentions. As the slogan of war-time activity was
"If you can't fight, work," so ours should be, "If you can't
play, sell."
Those who are familiar with Hopkins athletics believe
that it will be necessary to once gain the patronage of local
sport lovers to obtain their constant support. The fifteen
thousand dollars involved is not, therefore, the greatest aim
of the spring sale. The resultant interest of the public is the
fondest desire.

MUSICAL CLUB TO ELECT OFFICERS AT SUPPER
Officers for next- year's season
of the Musical Club will be elected at a supper to be held in the
Barn on March 22. This meeting
will consist of a gathering of all the
members . of the Musical Club,
Who are expected to be present in
order to vote for next year's executives. Although the club's
season is not closed, the officers
are to be installed immediately
after this election. This is to
give the new men a chance to
learn the duties of their offices
under the guidance of the retiring officers.

of the curtain in the first act until Armand de Treviere had made his
final escape, "The Purple Mask," a mystery-drama in five acts, was presented by the Johns Hopkins Dramatic Club at the Lyric Monday and
Tuesday nights.
The dullness of amateur performances is proverbial. "The Purple

was a distinct success. The members of the cast displayed ability far

In announcing fifteen thousand dollars as a goal, Mr.
Palmer believes that he has set a target which should be an
easy "bull-eye" for any wide-awake undergraduate body of
seven hundred students.
Opportunity is here offered to that large group of men
who ever bewail their inability to participate in college athletics, yet who always find fault with their progress, to prove
their good intentions. As the slogan of war-time activity was
"If you can't fight, work," so ours should be, "If you can't
play, sell."
Those who are familiar with Hopkins athletics believe
that it will be necessary to once gain the patronage of local
sport lovers to obtain their constant support. The fifteen
thousand dollars involved is not, therefore, the greatest aim
of the spring sale. The resultant interest of the public is the
fondest desire.

OTHER CAMPUSES
SERENADING LIMITED
Serenading the university students
at the University of Washington
after 8:30 on any night other than
Friday or Saturday is forbidden by
a rule passed by the student affairs
committee. The rule is a result of
complaints made by residents that
serenading late in the night disturbed their sleep.

WHAT NEXT?
Co-eds at Indiana University, it is
rumored, are going back to the oldfashioned shawls. The new shawls
are made of silk and are all colors of
the rainbow. They are worn knotted
around the neck, regular cow-girl
style.
